content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea and enjoyed it

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: A little too complicated for a clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved but please remove "with 1 roommate" from the preformatted output

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easily solvable

Will be taking everyone's feedback into account, and revising the clash.

Thanks for your input and suggestions :]

I'm going to omit roommates for simplicity.

EDIT: 
I believe everything should be updated in a way that makes it a little quicker to solve and easier to follow. Please let me know if it's still too much or if you have any suggestions/ideas/corrections!

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Sorry, but I don't think this is a good fit for clash of code. It's very complicated and would take at least 5 minutes to even understand the problem for most clashers. Stef_3 has also raised an issue where your solution isn't aligned with the statement (the statement asks for 'minimum roomates', but your code only checks 0 roommates and then jumps to the maximum number, not trying to optimise the roommate number).

I made some suggestions last week, but weren't implemented. I think this could be a good easy puzzle, but as a clash, it needs simplification to be solvable in 5 minutes.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Sorry but I'm rejecting it.
Description is too hard to even understand, definitely impossible to understand and solve in under 15 minutes. Too much "complex" words and clearly too long and imagine that in reverse mode... I'm rejecting it.
Even if this one doesn't pass I like the way you think, you should try to make something more understandable, keep going !

The Goal section says we're looking for the "minimum roommates needed"; but in your solution code it seems that you only try roommates = 0 and roommates = bed-1 (ie either no roommates or maximum roommates).

What if the house had many bedrooms, but Ruby only needs a few roommates?

For instance 
`2000 0.075 10000
1
100000 999/2 1500`

Income is monthly, mortgage rate is annual.

I am guessing living expenses are monthly, but I can't find that info in the statement. Could you please add "monthly" in front of "expenses" somewhere in the statement?

This is really quite complicated and challenging to solve in 15 minutes, and I don't think anyone could read and solve this in 5 minutes...

I failed to solve it in 15 minutes under clash conditions.

Some suggestions to simplify it:
1. Remove the possibility of roommates completely, just have clashers compare whether Ruby can afford these places on her own with the expenses each one would have, removing the "bed_bath" part from the inputs.
2. At least remove the bathrooms part and just have the number of bedrooms and assume that's the number of roommates she can have.
3. The extra string manipulation needed for 0 roommates to become "no" roommates is small, but for an already tough clash it could be the difference between finishing at 14m50s and not finishing at all.

I really think if you want people to solve this in 5-10 minutes, then you should simplify it to option 1. But this form could be good for an Easy puzzle?
very gud
Good looking clash.

Goal
* Paragraph 2: Suggest to change "a 10% down payment" to "a down payment of at least 10%".

* Please delete "(N)" because [[N]] is not a list.

* Please format "affordability", "roommates needed" and "spare monthly income" as [[variables]] instead of as {{constants}}.

* Key points: Suggest to merge the first two key points as follows:
Ruby is contributing her entire savings to the house as <<down payment>>, which should be at least {{10%}} of the house [[price]].

* Please format "loan" in <<bold>> or as a [[variable]] instead of as a {{constant}} (twice).

Input
* Line 1: Please mention that [[income]] and [[savings]] are integers while [[mr]] is a float.

* Please change the second "Line 1" to "Line 2".

* Next N lines:
(a) Please format "/" as a {{constant}}.

(b) Please add "separated by a space".

(c) Please mention that [[price]], [[be]], [[ba]] and [[expenses]] are all integers.

Output
* Please change the positive response as follows:
"{{Yes, the house is affordable with}} ([[minimum roommates needed]]/{{no}}) {{roommate(s) and $}}[[spare monthly income]] {{to spare.}}"

Constraints
* Test 3 and Validator 3 violate the price constraint. Please fix the constraint.

Cases
* Test 3: Please add an unaffordable scenario.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer".

Thanks.

Really helpful feedback, thank you!

-Updated Goal, I agree with everything you said.
-Updated Input. Would have missed this! I'm used JS, and variable declarations aren't SUPER important with JS.
-Updated Output. Thank you! 
-Updated Constraints - Added "=" -
Updated Cases - Added a case where the monthly expense was more than income for Test and Validator 3. (unaffordable)
Updated stub-Added write answer  as an example output


Thanks again for your input and time :)

Corrected expenses to be clearly stated that they are monthly, to the point of your first comment.

I think I coded for roommates dynamically in my initial solution, but can't remember. In other news though, I'll be removing roommates entirely so that this problem is a little more digestible as a clash. I appreciate the input greatly!

Sorry for the delay on replies, I unexpectedly got busy shortly after creating this.

No worries! Everyone had very valid feedback and criticism that I'm taking into account.
I appreciate the complement :)

I never intended this for reverse mode, and won't be making it a valid game mode for the clash.

Thanks again!

Thank you for the feedback!
After reviewing everyone's input, I completely agree that it was way too complex with the roommates and such.

I was busy at the time of your initial reply, and didn't have time to read or implement the suggestions. However, i fully agree with everything you had to say, and your alternate ways the clash could work, and get rid of some complexity, were much appreciated.

Good catch, missed that when removing roommates from the problem.

Thanks :) Adjusted

Thanks for the feedback.

Just generally too complicated, or do you think there's anything in specific that's making it too complex? I'd like to make it more simple if people think that it's too complex, but I'm really satisfied with the current problem, and am struggling to find ways to make it easier to follow without removing some of the core elements that make me want to have this as a clash.

No problem!

Just one more fix in the revised version:

Input
* Please change "int" to "integer" (twice) as the statement should be written in English instead of any programming language / short form as much as possible.

Thanks.
Gotcha, Updated!

Two more fixes after a fresh look:

Output
* Please format "$" as part of the {{constant}}.

* Please mention the rounding requirement of [[spare monthly income]].

Thanks.

adjusted accordingly!
Thanks for looking it over again :) was secretly hoping you would do so after I made the changes.

Does the format of me mentioning that [[spare monthly income]] is  (rounded down) look okay? Is there a better way to format that? Or should I mention it somewhere else in the problem?
I did also go ahead and include it in the goal, as it seems like it should be there too*

Yes, it looks fine now. Since it's just two words (rounded down), it won't look too verbose to repeat in different sections.

I usually check a contribution whenever it (re)appears as new (at the bottom of the contributions page, even if I've reviewed it  before) or when it gets approved/rejected. Usually only the first review is a thorough one; the subsequent reviews are more like quick scans.
Your diligence and expertise are always much appreciated ! :3
